titleStmt.title: Structure in the noise: understanding temporal variability in perceptual decision-making

analytic.title: Structure in the noise: understanding temporal variability in perceptual decision-making

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Studies of perceptual decision-making typically present the same stimulus repeatedly over the course of an experimental session but ignore the order of these observations, assuming unrealistic stability of decision strategies over trials. However, even so-called 'stable', 'steadystate' or 'expert' decision-making behavior features significant trial-to-trial variability that is richly structured in time. Structured trial-to-trial variability of various forms can be uncovered using latent variable models such as hidden Markov models and autoregressive models, revealing how unobservable internal states change over time. Capturing such temporal structure can avoid confounds in cognitive models, provide insights into inter-and intra-individual variability, and bridge the gap between neural and cognitive mechanisms of variability in perceptual decisionmaking.

div.head: Trial-to-trial variability in perceptual decision-making
div.p: As we move around the world, we constantly make decisions about incoming sensory information:

Has the traffic light turned green? How fast is the cyclist riding towards me? Is this fruit ripe, or will it give me a stomachache? Such perceptual decision-making is notoriously variable -we make different choices, even based on the same information. Classical models of perceptual decision-making assume that decision variability arises because of unstructured noise (IID, independent and identically distributed) in sensory processing, motor execution, or decisionmaking (Drugowitsch et al., 2016;Green & Swets, 1966;Ratcliff & McKoon, 2008). While these models may account for the amount of decision variability, they mostly ignore its ubiquitous temporal structure: patterns of choices and reaction times that are correlated in time.
Temporal structure unfolds over timescales from seconds (sensory adaptation, e.g. afterimages)
to minutes and hours (fatigue, learning), and years (development and aging) ( Figure 1a). This temporal structure has long been noted (Gilden et al., 1995;Wagenmakers et al., 2004).

Currently, new latent variable models developed in systems neuroscience and mathematical psychology capture both the overall distribution of variability as well as trial-by-trial estimates of latent, time-varying decision strategies. These models then allow decomposing observed behavioral variability into different sources: unmodelled but deterministic, versus probabilistic or truly random. Considering trial-to-trial structure in cognitive models has three distinct benefits: first, avoiding confounded scientific conclusions about cognitive models of decision-making; second, characterizing the rich diversity of behavioral strategies and solutions that individuals may adopt; milliseconds seconds minutes hours months years 10 -3 10 -2 10 -1 10 0 10 1 10 2 10 3 10 4 10 5 10 6 10 7 and third, as a basis for linking cognitive to neural variability. The latter two are part of a larger trend in neuro-and cognitive science, where variability and diversity (both between and within individuals) is increasingly appreciated rather than averaged away (Gomez-Marin & Ghazanfar, 2019;Krakauer et al., 2017;Musall et al., 2019).

Here, I review recent progress in capturing the temporal structure of decision variability, and technological and methodological developments that make this progress possible. The focus is on models capturing latent trial-to-trial variability that is internally generated, rather than inherited from external stimulus items (Ratcliff et al., 2018), suboptimalities and heuristics (Gardner, 2019;Rahnev & Denison, 2018) or experimenter-defined stimulus sequences (Meyniel et al., 2016).

div.head: A catalogue of models for latent trial-to-trial variability
div.p: Various potential model classes can be used to capture structured decision variability: from slowly drifting autoregressive models and discrete state switches to systematic updates ( Figure 1b; Table 1) (Owens & Fulcher, 2024). In principle, structured variability may arise when observers select different strategies ('regimes' or 'mental sets') over time, or from changing the parameters of a given strategies -these are ends of a spectrum, where large parameter jumps could be considered a different strategy. Each cognitive model may include stochastic and deterministic components. This overview focuses on models that have recently been used to extract latent single-trial variables that can be linked to neural or physiological data, making them of most interest to scientists studying the cognitive and neural mechanisms of (perceptual) decisionmaking.

div.head: Random noise
div.p: The easiest way to deal with temporal structure is to assume it doesn't exist. In this fashion, statistical models taught in every undergraduate psychology program (ANOVA's, GLMS) assume that observations are IID: they have independent error terms, and the distribution they are drawn from is stationary (Owens & Fulcher, 2024). For instance, signal detection theory assumes that the internal representation of repeated sensory stimuli is corrupted by independent Gaussian noise (for instance from stochastic firing of visual neurons) creating variability in responses (Green & Swets, 1966). The popular drift diffusion model (DDM) includes not just within-trial noise, but also trial-to-trial variability in drift rates, starting point and non-decision time. These across-trial variability parameters are crucial to account for specific aspects of human response time distributions (Boehm et al., 2018;Ratcliff & McKoon, 2008). While it has long been noted that some part of decision variability may arise from systematic updates (e.g. starting point variability may be generated by sequential effects), trial order is usually ignored in sequential sampling model fits (Fengler et al., 2022) and variability is assumed to be stationary. Generally, if we squeeze all our unexplained variance into a Gaussian noise term, much interesting temporal structure remains hidden.

Across-trial behavioral variability may also arise when organisms actively generate computational noise (Findling & Wyart, 2021), the level of which can be strategically adjusted to task demands (Tervo et al., 2014), which may help trade-off exploration and exploitation. Random decision variability is a potential 'behavioral marker' used in computational psychiatry, and increases with age and various brain disorders (Judd et al., 2024;Mansouri et al., 2024; but see Perquin et al., 2023), which may be useful in building dynamic 'computational phenotypes' that may improve diagnostic validity beyond average choice behavior (MacDonald et al., 2006;Schurr et al., 2024).

Trial-to-trial stochasticity in early sensory responses Drift Autoregressive model When = 1, special case of a Gaussian random walk (Chakravarty et al., 2024;Roy et al., 2021): humans can be instructed verbally about the structure and goals of the task, reduce task exploration, and regular breaks in human psychology experiments may reduce fatigue and task disengagement.

div.p: Yet, even highly motivated human observers show substantial history-dependent choice biases (Fründ et al., 2014) and fluctuations between internal and external modes of processing (Weilnhammer et al., 2023), suggesting that human strategy fluctuations may be subtle yet ubiquitous.

Dynamic choice biases are a striking example of how structured variability can confound scientific conclusions. If choice biases drift randomly over the course of a session, they will create sequential effects in the data -suggesting that observers systematically repeat their choices (Gupta & Brody, 2022;Lak et al., 2020;Vloeberghs et al., 2024) or even perform confidenceweighted reinforcement learning (Gupta & Brody, 2022;Lak et al., 2020), even when in fact no systematic updating occurs. The assumption of stable choice biases (e.g. to repeat past choices) causes model misspecification, leading to false inferences when choice biases instead fluctuate slowly over trials. Including drifting parameters in a model of choice behavior allows disentangling them from systematic updates, with the additional benefit of providing a trial-to-trial estimate of fluctuating biases that can be linked to neural and physiological data (Gupta & Brody, 2022;Vloeberghs et al., 2024).

div.head: State switches
div.p: A decision-maker can also jump between discrete strategies or internal states, for instance when mind-wandering leads to a period of 'off-task' focus. Influential models in cognitive psychology have treated behavioral data as arising from a mixture of processes, where some (random) trials are characterized by the 'failure to engage' (de Jong, 2000) or an 'attentional lapse' (Wichmann & Hill, 2001). However, lapse trials do not occur randomly in time (Pisupati et al., 2021). This temporal structure can be captured with hidden Markov models (HMM), which assume that a system transitions with some probability between states, each with its own generative parameters (Visser, 2011). Crucially, they do not just describe the decision strategy per state and the temporal dynamics of transitioning through them (in a so-called 'transition matrix'), but also assign the most probable state to each trial in a session -adding trial-by-trial temporal resolution. These models have a long history in mathematical psychology, where they have mostly been used to capture states that are induced by experimental conditions (Archambeau et al., 2023;Dutilh et al., 2011;Kucharský et al., 2021). Recent work has used HMMs to extract the timing of spontaneous state switches, for instance between engaged and disengaged states (Ashwood et al., 2022;Gunawan et al., 2022;Li et al., 2024;Weilnhammer et al., 2024). Conceptually similar, a novel Bayesian model by (Maggi et al., 2024) allows extracting precisely when an animal switches between rulebased and exploratory decision strategies during learning. Promisingly, this model can be fit on small numbers of trials, opening exciting avenues for real-time analysis during an experiment.

These models have brought several insights. Including disengagement states in model fits improves parameter estimation and cognitive model fitting (Li et al., 2024). They may also offer insight into mind-wandering and exploration of internal states with high temporal resolution (Banellis et al., 2024;Schooler et al., 2011). HMM-derived engagement states can also be linked to specific neural and physiological signals that may be conserved across species, from rodents to monkeys and humans (Bolkan et al., 2022;Hulsey et al., 2024;Tlaie et al., 2024). Lastly, they offer a powerful way to study the (neuro)physiological antecedents of state transitions, which may allow predicting state switches before they occur (Hulsey et al., 2024;Johnson et al., 2024).

div.head: Systematic updates and rhythms
div.p: On the most deterministic end of the spectrum, a plethora of update rules (based on properties of either current stimuli or past events) have been used to capture aspects of behavior. Studies of learning and order effects go back more than a century, and an extensive literature (not reviewed here) has documented various such sequential effects (Fischer & Whitney, 2014;Gao et al., 2009) and learning rules (Collins & Shenhav, 2022). One specific form of such an rule is an oscillatory process, creating rhythms in behavior -for instance, between internally and externally directed cognitive processes (Weilnhammer et al., 2023). Studies of systematic update rules underlying learning and decision-making often assume that behavior is in some ways optimal (Rahnev & Denison, 2018), that any systematic biases or learning rules are stable over time, and that they make a deterministic contribution to behavior.

If such systematic factors are missing from our model, they will leave variability unexplainedwhich may wrongly be interpreted as behavioral stochasticity or noise. To determine what fraction of choice variability arises from unknown systematic factors instead of random within-trial noise (Figure 1c), so-called 'double-pass experiments' show participants the exact same stimulus sequence twice (Ratcliff et al., 2018;Wyart, 2018;. The consistency of decisions between repeated stimuli then quantifies deterministic biases, the remainder unpredictable noise. These experiments show that around two-thirds of choice variability is accounted for by so-called computational noise in the inference process, rather than from stimulus-specific biases that are consistent across repeats (Beck et al., 2012;Drugowitsch et al., 2016;Findling & Wyart, 2021). However, computational noise may include systematic biases that vary across trials, so this is likely an overestimation of the degree of true stochasticity in human choice behavior. Recent work shows that artificial neural networks can be a powerful tool for distinguishing deterministic but unknown biases from true noise in data (Ger et al., 2024), with ever-more complex models approaching the noise floor of human choice variability.

In sum, different models are increasingly used to capture decision variability with specific temporal structure. These models can help avoid false scientific conclusions (Vloeberghs et al., 2024), map individual differences in decision strategies (Maggi et al., 2024) and provide latent variable estimates that can be linked to (neuro)physiological data (Tlaie et al., 2024), enriching our understanding of the dynamic nature of perceptual decision-making.

div.head: Putting latent variable models into practice
div.p: What is the behavior we fit our models to?

To compare how well different models can explain decision-making, we first need to define what we mean with 'behavior' and specify a model that describe how it arises. The simplest measurement of decision-making behavior is the binary choice, and its relation to the stimulus (which is usually modelled as a weighted coin flip, (Carandini, 2024)) -on which a century of psychophysical theory has been built. With modern model-fitting methods, a remarkable amount of trial-to-trial latent structure can be extracted from a simple sequence of stimuli and choices (Ashwood et al., 2022;Bruijns et al., 2023;Cuturela et al., 2024;Gupta & Brody, 2022;Roy et al., 2021;Vloeberghs et al., 2024), especially when data is combined across many trials and/or individuals.

When modelling response times (RTs), a prominent temporal pattern is the 1/f autocorrelation structure: a pattern of long-range serial dependence where the power of fluctuations is inversely proportional to their frequency (Gilden et al., 1995). While often hidden in the error bars of condition averages, this 1/f structure can account for a substantial portion of RT variance -on par with the effect of experimental conditions themselves (Perquin et al., 2024). While the 1/f structure in RT timeseries has been heralded as revealing the fundamentally dynamical nature of cognition, its existence does not point to a specific generative process. In principle, a mixture of various short-term processes (including regime switching) can lead to long-range dependencies in RT timeseries (Wagenmakers et al., 2004). Indeed, a combination of multiple deterministic, short-term memory mechanisms (of past stimuli, choice accuracy and decision fluency) can explain a large fraction of 1/f scaling in response times (Miletic et al., 2024).
Modelling either choices or RT provides a limited read-out of the decision process: more information about trial-to-trial latent structure can be extracted by modelling them jointly.

Sequential sampling models (also called evidence accumulation models) are the most common observation models that predict choices together with response time (RT) distributions. The most basic of these models assume that across-trial variability is not preset (Brown & Heathcote, 2008) or is IID (Ratcliff & McKoon, 2008). More recent model variants have added across-trial variability that follows systematic update rules (Fengler et al., 2022;Miletić et al., 2020;Pedersen et al., 2017), autoregressive or switching dynamics (Kucharský et al., 2021;Schumacher, Schnuerch, et al., 2023), often with impressive recovery of complex temporal structure. Variance decomposition in sequential sampling models comes with an additional challenge: these models do not predict a specific RT on each trial, but rather a distribution across trials. It is thus difficult to define a single-trial 'goodness of fit' measure, as is more straightforward when counting how many binary choices a model correctly predicts. Instead, as across-trial terms increasingly capture RT variability, cognitive models can quantify the decrease in estimated within-trial variability. This may point to a 'noise floor' of unpredictable variability that cannot be captured by any information about the order of observations in a session (Figure 1c). Quantifying at which point our models no longer explain additional variability can give crucial information about the irreducible sources of stochasticity in the system (Renart & Machens, 2014;.

What further measurements may help us approach this noise floor of predicting behavior? Going beyond choices and RT (as well as confidence ratings), arguably the workhorses of decades of psychophysics, a wealth of behavioral information can be extracted from task-unrelated behavior obtained from video recordings (Datta et al., 2019;Musall et al., 2019

div.head: Model comparison and misspecification
div.p: Having specified what phenomenon to explain, we face the second choice of determining which model best captures the psychological process generating it -keeping in mind that the models described (Table 1) are probably all useful and certainly wrong. The models discussed so far are only specific instances of a broader family of ever-complex models that may capture latent temporal structure -it is unlikely that the true model of any cognitive process is included in our overview. Some models do not specify a functional model class (such as reinforcement learning or autoregressive drift) but rather (parametrically or non-parametrically) estimate the shape of decision variability (Cochrane et al., 2023;Gunawan et al., 2022), which can help to flexibly fit data when there are few prior hypotheses about the nature of across-trial temporal structure (Schumacher, Bürkner, et al., 2023). (Gunawan et al., 2022;Schumacher, Schnuerch, et al., 2023) and mice (Ashwood et al., 2022). This points to the importance of testing to what extent discrete strategy changes are a fundamental feature of behavior across tasks and species.

div.head: Fitting increasingly complex cognitive models
div.p: A holy grail of cognitive modelling would be to fit a full model (combining all theoretically interesting candidate models) to behavior, quantify which terms dominate choice variability, and map the trial-to-trial latent variables to neural and physiological data. Increasingly complex models require sufficiently large trials numbers, and model fitting is complicated when likelihoods are intractable or very expensive to evaluate. Recent techniques combine advances in neural networks and simulation-based inference (Fengler et al., 2021;Rmus et al., 2024;Zammit-Mangion et al., 2024) to improve parameter fitting and latent variable inference (Jaffe et al., 2023;Pan et al., 2024). Specifically, amortized simulation-based inference allows training neural networks on simulated data from a generative model with temporal structure ('amortizing' or 'frontloading' the computation), which can then be used to efficiently fit larger families of complex models to empirical data (Boelts et al., 2022;Fengler et al., 2021;Schumacher, Bürkner, et al., 2023).
An exciting step for general modelling of across-trial temporal structure is offered by superstatistics approaches. They jointly fit an observation model (specifying how choices and

RTs are generated from a given decision strategy, e.g. a DDM) and a transition model (specifying how latent decision strategies change over trials, e.g. a hidden Markov model), which can take a specific functional form but imposes minimal constraints on how parameters change over time.

Neural superstatistics estimation can well recover latent temporal structure in simulated DDM data, where decision variability is either IID, follows a random walk, or switches between discrete values (Schumacher, Bürkner, et al., 2023;Schumacher, Schnuerch, et al., 2023). As the efficiency and ease-of-use of these modelling tools grows, flexible superstatistics fits may serve as a general first-pass data analysis to then inspire hypotheses about more specific cognitive and neural models that specify a data-generating mechanism (see Box 1).

Generally, fitting sequential sampling models requires many analysis choices to arbitrate between specific model variants: "with great flexibility comes a plethora of choices" (Schumacher, Schnuerch, et al., 2023) This flexibility leads to inaccessibility for the non-specialist user, who may struggle to choose between the many modelling choices, fitting packages and subtleties of model validation. As computational modelling ecosystems mature, community efforts to specify and share computational models in standardized formats (Gleeson et al., 2023) will be a crucial step towards moving from cottage-industry psychology to benchmarking models on 'big behavioral data' (Binz et al., 2024). In an ideal world, papers would not just present a specific combination of a dataset, a model and a fitting method, but systematically fill the space spanned by tasks, datasets, and cognitive models. As in any cognitive models, it is crucial to not rely only on simple model comparison metrics (such as BIC/AIC), but to find diagnostic patterns that falsify certain models (Palminteri et al., 2017) and to test the predictive power of our models through crossvalidation or additional experiments (Yarkoni & Westfall, 2017).

div.head: Concluding remarks and future perspectives
div.p: Scientific progress unfolds through incorporating ever-more observed phenomena in our models, reducing our uncertainties in predicting the world -to the extent possible (Glimcher, 2005). The phenomena inside our models change with new theories, methodologies and data: "one person's noise is another person's signal" (Uddin, 2020). One such phenomenon is increasingly escaping from our models' error terms into our description of cognition: structured variability in decisionmaking, unfolding over the course of seconds to minutes and hours.

To let go of the assumption that decision variability is simply random, stationary noise, recent work has explored ways in which temporal structure can be quantified as arising from drifting parameter values, discrete state switches, or a superposition of deterministic biases and updates.

This work has shown how cognitive models that continue to assume IID noise run the risk of Cognitive science is increasingly recognizing that not all people behave similarly, nor follow consistent behavioral strategies within a convenient laboratory session. The increasingly sophisticated toolkit of computational models can help us quantify this structured variability as a phenomenon that is crucial to capture for a richer understanding of cognition.

div.head: Box 1. What neural noise propagates to behavior?
div.p: What neural mechanisms give rise to variability in decision-making? At the single-neuron level, variability arises from stochasticity in vesicle release (Branco & Staras, 2009;Calvin & Stevens, 1968) and the opening and closing of voltage-gated ion channels in the cellular membrane (White et al., 2000). Action potential generation, on the other hand, is very precise (Mainen & Sejnowski, 1995). In general, single-neuron spiking noise may not contribute much to behavioral variability (Beck et al., 2012). Variability can also arise from the interactions between neurons: a recurrently connected circuit with balanced excitatory and inhibitory activity can produce neural spiking activity that closely resembles a Poisson distribution (Amit & Brunel, 1997;Vreeswijk & Sompolinsky, 1996). Networks of neurons can both amplify or dampen input noise, depending on their circuit connectivity (Faisal et al., 2008).

Behavioral variability is also tightly linked to fluctuations in internal state, an umbrella term for states like hunger, arousal, mood and attention (Greene et al., 2023;Uddin, 2020). Spontaneous behaviors (beyond task-based keypresses recorded in most psychology experiments) are increasingly used to account for fluctuations in neural data, giving noninvasive read-outs of a wide variety of bodily and physiological processes that shape behavior (Kluger et al., 2024;Musall et al., 2019;Tlaie et al., 2024). A biological process long recognized to explain variability in cognitive state is the release of modulatory neurotransmitters, which can Synapses Neural networks Internal state be linked to arousal fluctuations that can be measured non-invasively using the dilation of the pupil (McGinley et al., 2015). At the cognitive level, decision variability may arise from the high cost of maintaining cognitive control in tasks with experimenter-defined goals of reward maximization (Castiñeiras & Renart, 2022).

In general, choice variability is unlikely to map one-on-one to (neuro)physiological variability, but may arise from several mechanisms that produce variability across different levels of the nervous system (Faisal et al., 2008;Waschke et al., 2021) (Figure I). Low-level neural spiking noise could propagate to behavior or it may be averaged out, with deterministic computations then producing indeterminate, unpredictable behavior (Findling & Wyart, 2021;Glimcher, 2005). At the moment, we rarely have the data and computational methods to discover how and when low-level noise propagates to higher levels, and at what temporal and spatial scales we need to record the system to fully understand variability in behavior.

div.head: Box 2. The role of artificial neural network models
div.p: With ever-more complex models, how much behavioral variability can we ultimately hope to capture? A main disadvantage of classical cognitive models is that they are poorly predictive of observed behavior (Eckstein et al., 2023). To alleviate this problem, data-driven approaches using artificial neural networks (ANNs) have recently been proposed not just as fitting tools, but as cognitive models themselves (Binz et al., 2024;Eckstein et al., 2023;Rmus et al., 2024). These models exploit all possible sources of variability within the data, improving the predictive accuracy of trial-to-trial choices. ANNs can be a powerful tool in distinguishing deterministic but unmodelled variability from true stochasticity in behavioral data (Ger et al., 2024), with ever-more complex models approaching the noise floor of choice variability ( Figure 1c). Ultimately, including increasingly complete and high-resolution neural data may greatly improve our prediction of behavioral variability within and across individuals (Urai et al., 2022).

However, in their simplest form ANNs usually lack interpretability, the neural network acting as a "black box." The emergence of disentangled recurrent neural networks is just now making it possible to have the best of both worlds (Ji-An et al., 2023;Miller et al., 2023). These models are built with the same structure as classical recurrent neural networks, except that penalties are applied to information as it is passes through time. Effectively, each latent variable can represent a unique source of variability in the data and thus be extracted, interpreted, and tested against specific hypotheses. Rapid development in these interpretable ANNs promises exciting hybrid cognitive models, combining theory-driven constraints with data-driven model building to jointly improve interpretability and predictive accuracy (Yarkoni & Westfall, 2017).

div.head: Glossary
div.p: • Variability. A description of the degree and kind of variation in a dataset.

• Noise. Variability in a dataset that is not captured by the 'signal' in our models. May arise from unmodelled deterministic factors, deterministic unpredictability (chaos), or stochasticity. • Noise floor. The baseline level of variability that remains after accounting for known sources of structured variability. It represents the lower limit of detectable signal in experimental data and contains truly unpredictable or random fluctuations in decisionmaking. • Stochasticity. Unpredictability in a system's behavior that arises from true randomness or indeterminacy, where processes are governed by probabilistic rules rather than deterministic laws. • Independent, identically distributed (IID). Datapoints are independent of each other and are all drawn from the same statistical distribution. This means there is no temporal structure influencing the sequence. • Stationarity. A process where the statistical properties, like mean and variance, remain constant over time. Stationarity is an important assumption in time series analysis. • Latent variable model. A statistical model that infers unobserved 'latent' variables from observed data. • 1/f Noise. Any signal with a power spectrum that falls off steadily with increasing frequency.

It is often found in complex systems (including behavioral timeseries), and is also called 'pink noise'. • Autoregressive model. A family of statistical models used for analyzing and forecasting time series data, based on the assumption that a system evolves from some combination of its past states. • Hidden Markov model (HMM). A statistical model that assumes a Markov process (where the distribution of future states depends only on the present state) with unobserved (hidden) states. • Oscillation. Periodic fluctuations in a system, often used to describe rhythmic activity.

• Simulation-based inference. Using simulation to infer the likely parameters of a model, particularly useful for complex models where traditional inference methods may not be feasible. • Amortized likelihoods. The pre-computation of likelihoods in probabilistic modeling, enabling fast inference by reusing computational results. Amortized likelihoods are usually deployed in machine learning to speed up inference after an initial computational investment.

figure.head: Figure 1 .
figure.figDesc: Variability in decision-making. (a) Timescales (top) and sources of variability (bottom) in behavior; the blue zone indicates the duration of a typical experimental session. (b) Mapping the structure of decision variability: model classes ranging from stochastic (random white noise, drift, discrete state switches) to deterministic (systematic updates, oscillations) have all been linked to trial-to-trial choice variability. Code to generate time courses at https://github.com/anne-urai/decision-variability. (c) As models capture more complex sources of predictable variability, we can estimate the 'noise floor' of unpredictable stochasticity in decision-making behavior.

missing aspects of behavior that are core to biological cognition. Incorporating various forms of structured decision variability in our models can help avoid false scientific conclusions (for instance when drifting decision parameters can mimic confidence-dependent learning), capture between-and within-person variability in decision-making, and provide time-resolved latent variable estimates that can be linked to fluctuations in (neuro)physiological data. However, the models reviewed are currently largely descriptive, capturing patterns in data that were previously hidden in error bars. An important avenue for future research is to examine what insights about cognition may change when we take structured variability into account in our models of decisionmaking.

figure.head: Figure I .
figure.label: I
figure.figDesc: Noise in single neurons arising from vesicle release and synaptic stochasticity; noise in circuits from excitation/inhibition balance; and variability in behavior from mixtures of cognitive strategies, mind-wandering and spontaneous bodily and physiological states. Dashed lines between each stage highlight the challenge of determining how variability propagates between levels of spatial and temporal scale. Created in BioRender, https://BioRender.com/p13s394

figure.head: Table 1 .
figure.figDesc: Cataloguing latent variable models to account for trial-to-trial structure in decision-making data.

row.cell: The parameters governing decision-making may not only vary randomly from trial-to-trial, but also
include a short-term memory of its past state. For instance, time-varying arousal levels will affect
our attention to the visual stimulus, leading to slow changes in perceptual sensitivity over multiple
trials. Recent models have implemented such time-varying parameters of a cognitive model as
an autoregressive (AR) process, where the state of the system is a linear function of its previous
state(s) and some noise. Response times (RT) timeseries are often modelled using
autoregressive models, showing that the structured variability in RTs is a stable individual trait
with high test-retest reliability across sessions (Perquin et al., 2023).
Autoregressive models can also be used on sequences of choices to reveal how parameters of
the decision process fluctuate over trials. For instance, the autoregressive model PsyTrack
assumes that the weights of a psychometric function (of e.g. stimuli, bias and previous choices)
evolve over trials according to a Gaussian random walk -a special case of an AR model where

figure.figDesc: Roy et al., 2021) (Table 1). This model can recover the trial-to-trial weights of each regressor from behavioral timeseries and has been used to track the dynamics of choice strategies in multiple species. For example, in mice that show seemingly stable performance on a decision-making, this model reveals time-varying phases of bias towards specific choice options(Zhu & Kuchibhotla, 2024): what might seem random errors or poor task engagement may instead reflect active and adaptive exploration of the environment. This highlights the importance of modeling temporal dynamics to uncover adaptive strategies that may otherwise be hidden in apparently suboptimal decision-making.So far, it remains an important open question how much choice biases and other decision-making parameters fluctuate in humans during a typical decision-making experiment, and when such drifts affect scientific conclusions. Multiple factors may lead to more stable psychometric parameters in humans as opposed to rodents

It would also be naïve to assume that any single latent variable model can capture all behavioral variability -mixtures are likely necessary to understand variability within and between individuals.So far, models are commonly contrasted with a 'baseline' of IID noise, which can be easily obtained by shuffling trials. Direct comparison of different model classes is rare, and sometimes complex. When models are directly compared, the comparison is usually restricted to one or a
figure.note: handful of models. A few studies highlight the importance of direct model comparison to disentangle candidate mechanisms. In studies that compared discrete state switches (HMMs or mixture random walks), with drifting (autoregressive or random) models, state switches best explained strategy fluctuations in both humans
